intro: Chenopodium album var. acuminatum, commonly known as sharpleaf lambsquarters, is an annual herbaceous plant native to Europe, Asia, and North Africa. It is characterized by its alternate, ovate to lanceolate leaves that are often covered in fine hairs and have a pointed or acuminate tip. The plant produces small, greenish flowers arranged in dense, terminal clusters, and its seeds are dispersed by wind. It thrives in disturbed soils and is often found in agricultural fields, roadsides, and waste areas. Due to its rapid growth and adaptability, it is considered a common weed in many regions.
